author: Hiro Goto
title: Incentivizing Interaction (Phase 2)
description: Much-needed breakthrough innovations can be achieved by incentivizing interactions among people from different backgrounds.

assessments.note:
It is unclear to me what the proposal actually proposes. So I have to guess that it's a project think tank incubator. If so the community might benefit from this. 
It is also not clear what the proposal concludes. Is it a plan to create a communications platform? 
I don't see much value in how this could onboard people to the Catalyst community.

The proposal doesn't make it clear which problem it is seeking to solve. There is no indication of how the proposal is related to the challenge. I recommend that the proposal be included in an appropriate challenge, changed to suit a challenge, or if the proposer believes that there is no challenge related, there is the possibility of creating a new Challenge setting.
Possible a germ of a good idea here. Bring together diverse people to make better proposals. No real plan on how deliver on this.

I think that the idea itself is good, but the approach chosen to do it is not the best one. The idea of breaking down the project into 8 phases creates a high risk of not receiving the desired fund or a big part of it. Also, referencing full books in order to explain why the idea is good is a bad approach, because most people don't have the time to read them, or even research about what they say. It is also not clear that in the context of Catalyst, this kind of interaction would make a huge improvement in quality of proposals in comparison to what they are today.

The proposor works for a Japanese government subcontractor regarding innovation projects. There is no mention of how this project would attract people from outside of the community. Nor is there a mention of any way to market this and get it known to the public.

There are no details on the proposer's qualification / experience, just a vague mention that he works for a company related to the Japanese government.

The plan needs to be more detailed, there is no clarity in the purpose of the proposal or how it is related to the challenge, there is no timeline in the roadmap. There is no budget breakdown.

I recommend including this information so that we can understand the concept of the proposal and give more appropriate feedback.

How will you measure diversity? How will you reward it? How will you bring on the stakepool operators you want to fund this? This proposal has no clear goal on how to achieve its object thus is unlikely to succeed in its current form.

The proposal doesn't have enough information about the person or team behind the idea, and there is no clear roadmap for Phase 2, about what would be executed. The Phases 1 and 2 seem to have some overlap and it's also not clear when one finishes and the other starts. The budget should be broken down to better understand how the money would be spent.

The information provided to assess this is too lean. 
To clarify: the plan is way too vague to determine what is actually being proposed. 
There are no metrics set. What would success look like? 
There is no funding breakdown to justify the 50k USD asked for.

There is not enough information to audit the proposal efficiently.

First of all, it is important to define the relationship between the proposal and the challenge, if there is such a relationship it is important to define details for the proposal plan, such as timeline / roadmap, milestones, KPIs, details about the budget and about the team / proposers.

I recommend that the proposer ask the community or a mentor for help and follow the Catalyst documentation to write the proposal.

There is no real plan against which progress can be measured. Proposer wants to incentivise interaction for interactions sake. How does that work. If people interact for interactions sake, what role does incentivisation have?

In regard of Phase 2, the proposal lacks a plan, roadmap, milestone, KPIs and metrics. More information should be included regarding all the topics mentioned above in order to make the proposal auditable. Also, risks of not receiving funds for any of the phases should be better evaluated, since now it just says that this could happened and the project should be flexible and adapt.

solution: Incentivising interaction among people of different backgrounds (the greater the difference, the bigger the reward) brings about innovations
experience: My company supports the Japanese government program called innovation.
